<math alttext="f of x, equals, the fraction with numerator x, and denominator the absolute value of x, end fraction, for x not equal to 0; f of x equals, 0, for x equals 0." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mo>{</mo><mtable columnalign="left"><mtr><mtd><mfrac><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>|</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>|</mo></mrow></mfrac></mtd><mtd><mrow><mtext>for</mtext><mspace></mspace><mspace width="0.45em"></mspace><mi>x</mi><mo>≠</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mtd><mtd><mrow><mtext>for</mtext><mspace></mspace><mspace width="0.45em"></mspace><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>
If <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the function defined above, then <math alttext="the limit as x approaches 0, of, f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></munder><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the classification of a given expression (e.g., Use the chain rule to find the derivative of a composite function).
